Key Match Events: The game turned into a slugfest with both teams combining for 21 runs.
The Cardinals came away with a 14-7 win.
The Yankees' bullpen allowed nine runs (eight earned) in the seventh inning.
Tommy Kahnle couldn't record another out after getting Brendan Donovan to line out to left fielder Alex Verdugo.
Phil Bickford threw the ball past first baseman Anthony Rizzo, allowing Victor Scott II to score.
Pre-Game Insights: As bad as people think we are playing … we are still in first place,” starter Nestor Cortes said.
It’s there for us to take. We just have to come out every day prepared and be ready to win every single day.”
Post-Match Reflections: Aaron Boone said, “The difference is, we couldn’t close out that inning. We were still tied with two outs when they got all of those five runs,”
Tommy Kahnle acknowledged, “I got behind a couple of counts. I made some bad pitches,”

Aaron Boone said, “We know how important these games are. Another opportunity to win a series that we weren’t able to finish and that sucks, but it’s onward. … We have to play our best, and we have to put our best foot forward to win these games. And we hope we start that tomorrow night.”
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was a slugfest with the ball bouncing the wrong way for both sides.
New York has lost four of its past five games and finds itself one-half game ahead of the second-place Orioles in the American League East.
Anthony Rizzo, playing in his first game since June 16, highlighted the scoring with a double to left field in the fifth inning, scoring Jazz Chisholm Jr. from first.
Others: The Cardinals had a really good day offensively, putting the ball in play pretty well against Nestor Cortes.

The Yankees didn't have the most reliable defense behind Cortes, with Donovan leading off with a fly ball that looked routine for Soto, but he kept going back before the ball went over his head for a double.
